text: A Worksite Smoking Cessation Intervention Involving the Media and Incentives I
This study evaluated an attempt at 38 workplaces to help employees stop or reduce their levels of smoking.
In past research, worksite support groups, in combination with a media smoking cessation program and self-help manuals , were found to be effective in helping employees quit smoking.
Unfortunately , recidivism was found at the follow-up evaluations.
The present study replicated the results of the previous worksite smoking cessation program with support groups, a television intervention, and self-help manuals.
At this postpoint, 42% of employees provided groups plus incentives were abstinent compared to only 15% who were only provided self-help materials.
An important difference in this study was that there were also monthly follow-up support groups and incentives.
Work settings can be a source of stress and conflict, which can precipitate relapse.
At a 12 - month follow-up, 26% of those participants who were provided support and incentives were abstinent compared to 16% who were only provided the self-help materials.

During February 1987, approximately 6 weeks before the beginning of a television news series on smoking cessation, 14 volunteers agreed to be filmed as they went through the American Lung association's "Freedom from Smoking in 20 Days" program.
Of these 14 individuals, 10 completed the program.
Representing different population segments, these 10 volunteers allowed WLS, the local Chicago ABC television station, to follow them for 20 days.
The efforts of these participants were discussed during the news series to illustrate various segments of the program.
Begin~ng March 5, 1987, WLS began airing 10 - and 30 - second commercials, at various times during the day and evening, to promote the series.
These promotions continued throughout the news series.
Altogether, approximately 200 promotions were aired prior to the television smoking cessation series.
Tim Ryan, the station's special segment reporter, assumed a motivator's and instructor's role and provided the viewing audience with the stepby-step method to quit smoking.
The program was introduced on the 10 p.m. news,.
There were 19 subsequent segments on both the 4 p.m. and 10 p.m. news broadcasts.
Ratings during the broadcast indicated that approximately 300,000 people and 500,000 people, over 18 years old, watched the 4:00 and 10:00 WLS news, respectively.
In the present study, 38 corporations were involved, 19 worksites in each of two conditions.
When approximately 150 corporations were contracted, they were informed about the media-based program to occur in the Spring of 1987.
They were told that a randomly selected half of the corporations would be provided twice-weekly groups plus follow-up groups and incentives.
Only those corporations that expressed a willingness to have all components of the program (media, self-help manuals, groups, incentives) were included in the study.

The intention of this procedure was to identify corporations with similar degrees of interest in the overall program prior to randomly assigning corporations to group-incentive (G) and no-group (NG) conditions.
A central coordinator for the smoking cessation program, who was an employee of the company, was established at each of the participating corporations.
In the companies with groups, the central coordinators recruited employees as group leaders.
These leaders attended a training session that provided an overview of the project, and reviewed and reinforced the supportive function of their role.
The central coordinators also sent out a brief questionnaire to their employees to assess their smoking status and interest in participating in the program.
The group leaders were sent registration forms that contained the television program schedule and the self-help manuals.
The leaders then recruited those worksite employees who indicated an interest from the questionnaires.
In the NG condition, central coordinators recruited smokers who had expressed an interest in the program from the questionnaires.
The companies' group leaders scheduled six 45 - minute support group meetings, two a week during the 3 - week television program.

The group sessions focused on reviewing techniques discussed in the television program and self-help manuals° Following the 3 weeks of television programs and twice weekly group meetings, 1 - hour monthly meetings were held.
These followup groups emphasized how participants could utilize the supportive aspects of their social environment to aid quitting or remaining abstinent.
These 12 meetings over the next year were designed to help participants continue to receive support and encouragement.
During the final group session and at the 12 monthly follow-up meetings, there were two lotteries at each corporation.
Each group member who had been abstinent since the last meeting obtained one lottery ticket, and there was a drawing at the meeting with the winner obtaining $50.
In addition, every exsmoker wrote the names of up to five family members and up to five co-workers who had been helpful to them in remaining abstinent over the past month.
Another lottery was held with these names, and the winners obtained $50.
Only a few of the company-based incentive programs have extended rewards to employees who have never smoked, exsmokers, or family members of program participants.
This is unfortunate because rewards could motivate nonsmokers tovecome more supportive of the quitting effort.
If incentives are high, some nonsmokers could take up the habit to be rewarded for quitting, and others might resent the fact that smok-ers get incentives but not them.
In the present study, providing a lottery for both smokers and others helped avoid the problems mentioned above.

In the immediate posttest, 6 - month, and 12 - month follow-up interviews, the participants completed measures assessing participants' progress in reducing smoking, the frequency of using the self-help manual and watching the television series, and the number of group meetings attended.
Ratings also measured the helpfulness of the different smoking cessation techniques in the manual, the television series, and the groups.
Separate statistical analyses were conducted using the group and the individual as the unit of analysis, and similar results were found.
Because randomization occurred at the group level, corporations were the unit of analysis for comparisons reported in this article, unless otherwise indicated.
The average return rate for the preintervention surveys was 47% for Gs (group intervention) and 33 % for NGs (nongroup intervention), F(1, 36) = 4.25, p < .05.
The average number of employees in companies was 159 for Gs and 232 for NGs, F(1, 36) = 5.24, p < .05.
Four-hundred twentyseven smokers in G companies and 423 smokers in NG companies returned surveys (those who just smoked cigars or pipes were excluded).
Assuming an equal return rate for smokers and nonsmokers (this formula was previously used by , the smoking prevalence rate was 310/0 for G companies and 38% for NG companies, F(1,36) = 3.35.

For some companies central coordinators were able to provide us with the exact number of smokers, otherwise estimates were calculated by dividing the number of returned surveys completed by smokers by total number of returned forms, and multiplying this percentage by the total numbers of employees.
Among the 850 smokers who returned surveys, 71% of G smokers and 81% of NG smokers checked an item indicating they were interested in a 3 - week worksite smoking cessation program, F(1, 36) = 2.78.
A company representative approached the interested participants and provided them with more details of the program.

Of the 854 smokers who returned surveys, 61% of G smokers and 75% of NG smokers decided to join the programs, F(1, 36) = 5.63, p < .05. 2 Of those signing up for the program, the postpoint attrition rate for Gs was 17% and for NGs, 29%, F(1, 36) = 6.62, p < .05.
Attrition is defined as not attending any group meetings, not reading the manual, not being located for posttesting, refusing to be interviewed, changing jobs.

Table III presents results of program impact.
At postpoint, there was significant difference in the quit rates for G and NG conditions (42 vs. 15%).
At the 6 - month follow-up, an average of 29°70 of participants in the G condition and 20°7o of participants in the NG condition were not smoking?
At the 12 - month follow-up, 26% of Gs and 16°70 of NGs reported that they were not smoking.
5 Significantly more Gs (12O7o) than NGs (5O7o) reported not smoking continuously from postpoint to the 6 - month follow-up.
From postpoint to the 12 - month follow-up, significantly more Gs (11 °7o) than NGs (3°7o) indicated continuous abstinence.

There were significant differences in company-wide reduction in smoking for Gs and NGs at postpoint (10 vs. 3O/o), at the 6 - month follow-up (6 vs. 2O7o), and at the 12 - month follow-up (5 vs. 2o70).
There were no significant G versus NG differences in postpoint, and 6 - month, and 12 - month number of cigarettes, tar, nicotine, or carbon monoxide levels.
4At the 6 - month follow-up, 26 Gs and 32 NGs were not interviewed.
Some had moved, could not be reached despite numerous attempts to reach them, or refused to be interviewed.
At the individual level of analysis, significantly more Gs (26°70) than NGs (17o70) were abstinent, x2(1) = 4.75, p < .05.
the 6 - and 12 - month abstinence rate data in the text refer to individuals who indicated they had been abstinent for at least the last 7 days.
5At the 12 - month follow-up, 11 Gs and 18 NGs were not interviewed.
In addition, 6 Gs and 1 NG who were not interviewed at the 6 - month follow-up were interviewed at the 12 - month follow-up.
At the individual level of analysis, significantly more Gs (2507o) and NGs (16070) were abstinent, X2(1) = 4.81, p < .05.
"The participants told interviewers their brand of cigarette, and these brands were checked with the Federal Trade Commission Report to obtain tar, nicotine, and carbon monoxide levels.
bThe individual, rather than the corporation, was the unit of analysis.
bFor this item, the unit of analysis is the individual.
Data for this item was collected on 393 participants.
A group of 20 variables were selected that had possible theoretical interest in predicting participants' abstinence (unit of analysis was the individual).

These variables involved preintervention smoking history (i.e., number of years smoking, number of cigarettes consumed daily, longest number of days previously quit smoking), motivation (i.e., motivation to quit on a 4 - point scale, and four dummy variables involving the reason for wanting to quit: looks, social, family, and health), gender, number of group meetings attended, household size, postpoint social support (i.e., the extent another person was interested in the participant quitting, measured on a 4 - point scale; and a dummy variable assessing whether support was received from coworkers), the participants' perceived health status at postpoint that was measured on a 4 - point scale, intervention variables (i.e., how much the person read the manual and watched the television program using a 12 - point scale, how many ideas the participants recalled from the manual using a 9 - point scale, and how many aspects of the television program participants recalled using a 7 - point scale), and items representing problems the participants experienced at the postpoint during their efforts to quit (i.e., weight gain, stress, and being uncomfortable around other smokers, all measured on a 3 - point scale).
A backward stepwise logistic regression procedure, using SAS logist, was employed.
This procedure eliminated variables that were not significantly aOnly data from current smokers were used.
bRates were derived from participants who completed both the post point and the 6 - month interview.

If those not interviewed at the 6 - month follow-up (e.g., could not be reached, refused, etc.) are regarded as smokers, then the abstinence rate for group participants is 25°70 and for nongroup participants is 17%, F(1, 36) = 2.42.
Using a similar procedure at the 12 - month follow-up, 22% of Gs and 1207o of NGs were abstinent, F(1, 36) = 6.33, p < .05.
CContinuous nonsmoking refers to all individuals who stopped smoking at the program end and did not experience any relapse by the 6 - month follow-up.

Using a less stringent definition, for those who were quit at postpoint and at the 6 - month follow-up but might have had a brief relapse in between, there were significant group (20)°7o versus nongroup (6 %) differences, F(1, 36) = 12.06, p < .01.
Using a similar procedure at the 12 - month follow-up, 16% of Gs and 4% of NGs were continuously abstinent, F(1, 36) = 11.04, p < .01.
aAt the individual level of analysis, NGs (11.39) had significantly higher tar levels than Gs (9.46), F(1, 236) = 4.35, p < .05.
Only significant findings are reported below.

At postpoint time, those who quit smoking had more days of abstinence prior to the intervention (x z = 6.13, D = -.09) 6, were more motivated to quit (x z = 7.97, D = -.11), had attended more meetings (x 2 = 55.50, D = -.33), were less concerned about weight gain (X 2 = 9.92, D = . 12), and were less stressed (X z = 13.04, D = .15).

At the 6 - month follow-up, those who were abstinent had more days of abstinence prior to the intervention (X z = 9.65, D = -.14), had been less stressed at postpoint (X 2 --5.22, D = .09), had attended more group meetings (X z = 5.03, D = -.09), and had recalled more aspects of the television program (x z = 6.17, D = -. 10).

Finally, at the 12 - month follow-up, those who were abstinent had attended more group meetings (X z = 12.16, D = -.17), had recalled more aspects of the television program (X 2 = 4.45, D = -.08), and had smoked for fewer years (x 2 = 4.02, D = .07).

Of the individuals who indicated that they had quit smoking at the 12 - month follow-up, we were able to obtain biochemical verification (cotinine saliva tests) on 43 individuals (48% of the quitting sample).
In addition, for several individuals who had elevated scores on the cotinine test (n = 6) we also collected breath samples using an ecolyzer to measure the carbon monoxide in their breath.
Three of their scores were in the nonsmoking range (_< 9 ppm).
Many individuals were notable to be tested because of scheduling conflicts, they could not leave their jobs, or they had moved.

Attempts were made to obtain an independent confirmation of nonsmoking status from a co-worker or relative who knew the participant, and these calls were made to 81 participants (confirmation was obtained on 77% of this sample).
For each individual, the biochemical and confirmation data were used to determine if the person was a quitter or smoker.
In, 12 - month reported data refer conservatively to information where we are relatively sure that the person has quit, both biochemical and co-worker or relative confirmations.
In the G condition, 44 participants had quit at the 12 - month followup, and for the NG condition, 26 had quit smoking.
Incentives and supplies 6The X 2 is really a q statistic, and it usually closely agrees with the chi-square statistic.
The D statistic is like a partial R 2.
cost approximately $21,000 for the G condition, so each G quitter cost $477.
Supplies for the NG condition cost about $2,000, so each NG quitter cost $77.
estimated that in 1980 dollars, the average one-pack a day smoker costs an employer $469 each year.
Adding 5% annually to this amount to account for inflation, in 1987 dollars, this amount increases to $660.
Using this year, the 44 G quitters would have cost companies $29,040 whereas the 26 NG quitters would have cost companies $17,160.
Oster, estimated the total economic benefits of quitting fora moderate smoker who has been smoking for 19 years.
These benefits are only based on the probability of reducing costs due to coronary heart disease, lung cancer, and chronic pulmonary disease.
The estimated lifetime benefits are $34,693.
If the 44 Gs and 26 NGs maintain their abstinence, then the lifetime savings for Gs are $1,526,492 and for NGs, $902,018.
Finally, in terms of public health implications, over 50,000 self-help manuals were distributed with the program.
If only 15% were able to quit with these materials, then approximately 7,500 smokers were helped to quit with this media program.
The total economic benefits of quitting for this group, based on the estimates from would be $260,197,500.
The provision of twice-weekly discussion groups plus a lottery at work settings increased the short-term effectiveness of a televised self-help smoking cessation program.
In addition, monthly booster sessions plus the incentives were partially effective in helping participants maintain abstinence.
At the 6 - and 12 - month follow-up, there was a significantly higher reduction in the workforce smoking rates in G as opposed to NG companies.
While encouraging, these findings need to be interpreted with caution until longer term follow-up data are collected.
If continued positive findings do emerge, then future studies might need to disentangle the effects of group meetings and incentive use.
Attendance at group meetings was the strongest predictor of abstinence at the postpoint and 12 - month follow-up.
This is evidence of the continuing influence of the group intervention overtime.
In addition, variables tapping past smoking behavior were predictive of abstinence at all time points.
Participants with more successful prior attempts at quitting and shorter histories of smoking were more successful at quitting in the present program.
One aspect of the intervention, recalling aspects of the television program was predictive of abstinence at the 6 - and 12 - month follow-up.
Several variables tapping problems in quitting were significant at the end of the program, but by the 12 - month follow-up, these variables were no longer predictive.

Based on these findings, it appears that prior smoking history, attendance at group meetings, and recall of television components had the strongest role in longerterm quitting, whereas these variables in combination with problems in quitting influenced abstinence at the earlier time points.
suggested that worksite programs have the promise of being more successful than traditional clinic-based approaches.
In their review of seven studies using incentives-competition, the postquit rate averaged 45% and follow-up quit rate was 26% (if one study with an exceptionally high quit rate is excluded).
The average participation rate was 61%0 and the average attrition rate was 8%.
Results from the present study are comparable to these findings.

Taken together, these studies suggest that incentive-competition programs may motivate more smokers to attempt a quit effort, who in turn may achieve higher outcome rates, perhaps by encouraging social support.
Two recent, relatively well-controlled, worksite competition programs reported follow-up cessation rates of only 18 and 12%.
These authors concluded that programs might need to be designed that alter worksite-wide social norms and extend for longer periods of time.
The present study involved booster group meetings and incentives over 12 months in order to provide participants a more comprehensive and extended intervention.
Some participants did mention that shifting from twice-weekly to monthly meetings was abrupt.
Perhaps future interventions might fade the frequency of meetings so that the participants feel a more gradual reduction of social support.

Klesges and Cigrang (in press) reported that most worksite smoking cessation programs have not reported biochemical verification of quit status, participation rates, attrition rates, and percentage reductions in smoking at the worksite.
Data on these variables are reported in the present investigation.
In addition, only a few studies have used worksites as the unit of analysis, and this important methodological feature was built into the present study.

There are several variables that did differentiate the G and NG conditions (i.e., company size, percentage returning questionnaires, percentage signing up for the program, when the manual was received).
Even though randomization occurred at the corporation level, these preintervention variables might have had an effect on the results and the generalizability of the findings.
Still, the overall results are consistent with the literature on worksite smoking interventions and with the theoretical notions that provided the justification for this study.
Future research might attempt to better control preintervention variables perhaps by matching on key variables prior to randomizing.

In should be noted that the majority of smokers do quit on their own and that worksite programs do not reach some of the most high-risk smokers (e.g., unemployed, nonworking adults, seniors, young people).

Another important point is that the effects of the program might have been due to the performance of the worksite coordinators and group leaders, and future research should assess the influence of these key program implementers.
The present study represents one of the largest worksite smoking cessation efforts.
The results indicate that incentives plus booster meetings can decrease erosion of treatment gains.

Future research might investigate ways to obtain even higher cessation and maintenance rates by, for example, paying employees for attending meetings, introducing team competition, more actively recruiting buddies, and clearly securing support from top level management, adopting worksite policies that encourage no smoking, and creating new company-widenorms that support nonsmoking.
Pilot work with such variables, by the authors, has produced encouraging results.
Health and community psychologists maybe able to reduce the alarmingly high levels of smoking by creatively using incentives, group support meetings, self-help materials, and television broadcasts.
And, worksites area prime location for initiating smoking cessation efforts in order to reduce the number of American employees who smoke.
